content: Fixed typo "bewteen" to "between"
I've just changed the tag "State caching" to "Memoization".

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a popular puzzle and I love it.

The tie-break isn't  sufficient as stated. Example we have 100, 27, 26, 25, 24, 23 and we need to give 150.  We have 3 ways using 3 coins, but in every case the largest coin is 100.  

Change the wording to: If there are several solutions, choose the one where the first coin that is different is larger than the other.

At the moment there is an error with the stub in cpp where the register keyword is not being escaped. I will try to post it on the discord to see if they can fix it. It's not your fault, and it is properly escaped in C.

Edit: This is not really important and should not prevent anyone from approving the contribution.
challenging but fun !!

This is an example of a solution (ruby) that passes all tests but fails a validator (expires in one week): https://bpa.st/YCBA

I would suggest to add the failing validator "Nothing to do" as a separate public test and fill both the previous "Nothing to do" public test and the new one with new validators.

I commented in the code what is that would fix it.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy at first sight but more interesting once inside

Goal
* Please format "0" as a {{constant}}.

* Please change "and IMPOSSIBLE either" to "or {{IMPOSSIBLE}} if there is no solution".

Output
* Please change "biggest coin" to "coin of largest denomination".

* Please add "or {{IMPOSSIBLE}} if there is no solution".

Thanks.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is simple in its formulation, requires an interesting algorithm, and has a real life application.
and IMPOSSIBLE either. => or IMPOSSIBLE if there is no solution.

You still need to:
- Add a test case forcing state caching
- Explain "IMPOSSIBLE" case in statement

And by the way, this is not exactly "Memoization", as Memoization implies the result of a pure function has been cached. In this problem, we only need remember states that have been reached. So a better name would be "State Caching" (sometimes, it's also called "Visited Marking").

This testcase would be nice to force memoization:
91 92 93 94 95 96 97 98 99 101 102 103 104 105 106 107 108 109
9000

As there are many ways to reach 200, 400, 600, etc., solutions without memoization do not work.

Nice puzzle.
This is a very simple and interesting statement, yet the solution is not so simple.

My 2 cents:
- Shouldn't there be a case where there is no solution, such as:
5 10 20 50 100
23
- I usually use AI to improve the statement. Here is how ChatGPT 4-Omega would improve your it, so that it sounds less French-translated:

One of your friends came yesterday to ask for your help. He has opened a shop and wants to give change to his customers using the fewest coins possible. Unfortunately, he isn't very good at math and, knowing you are a computer engineer, he thought you could create a program to tell him which coins to give based on what is left in his cash register.

To simplify, let's assume there are enough coins of each denomination in the cash register.

Excuse me I didn't see this puzzle.

Though I think mine is a bit different : the puzzle you showed me there is all time every kinds of coins, and can so be solved with a greedy algorithm, while in my contribution you must use a BFS algorithm optimized with memoization to match all the test cases.

So I think that my contribution is not that unuseful...

Noted, I agree that your puzzle seems to require something different from the ones I've quoted.

Code / Cases
* Your solution code does not work correctly for the following cases. Please add these cases and fix your code:

1 5 10 25 100
1

1 5 10 25 100
5

1 5 10 25 100
25

1 5 10 25 100
100

Cases
* Please change "5432" to another value so that it won't violate the last constraint, and also change the list of coins so that a simple method will give the wrong answer.

Goal
* Please fix the typo: "freinds" => "friends".

* Please change "some help" to "for help".

* Please change "less coins" to "few coins".

* Please fix the typo: "registrer" => "register" (twice).

* Please change "there is" to "there are".

* Please delete "or bills".

* Please change "kind of monney" to "denomination".

(Also note that "monney" should be spelled as "money".)

Input
* Please fix the typo: "Ligne" => "Line" (twice).

* Please fix the typo: "registrer" => "register" (twice).

* Please fix the typo: "aviable" to "available".

Output
* Please fix the typo: "Ligne" => "Line".

* Please change "0" to "{{0}}" and remove the quotation marks.

Constraints
* Please change "monney" to "denomination".

* Please fix the typo: "registrer" => "register".

Title
* Please fix the typo: "registrer" => "register".

Stub generator
* Please fix the typo: "registrer" => "register".

Thanks.

Of course you passed all tests otherwise you could have not submitted your contribution.

Usually if there is a way of passing all tests but not all validators it is a hint that the coverage is not ideal. When the contribution gets published, those who commit the same mistake I did will receive no feedback and just silently fail the validation even though they may pass all the public tests.

It's more than enough indeed, but it violates your 0 <= goalAmount <= 10 000.
You can safely use an amount between 9000 and 10000, though.

The IMPOSSIBLE case is explained in the main statement, while the 0 case is explained in the Output description.

Ah ok, I missed that line. Then what about the weird money case with 1 3 5 coins, and if the goal was to give 6? Should it be 3 3 or 5 1? 
I know that such a case is not included, but as a player you can't currently be sure it is or is not included.

Maybe end the statement with something like: output the combination of coins that results in the least number of coins. For every case, there is only one solution.

Thank you very much for showing up this huge issue !

I'm going to fix that : in the case where there would be multiple solutions, you'd have to choose the one with the biggest coin.
